egregious.meaning_1: adjective: standing out in a negative way; shockingly bad
egregious.sentence_1: The dictator’s abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders demanded that he be tried in an international court for genocide.

maintain.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
maintain.sentence_1: The scientist maintained that the extinction of dinosaurs was most likely brought about by a drastic change in climate.

galvanize.meaning_1: verb: to excite or inspire (someone) to action
galvanize.sentence_1: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, “Go Kyle”; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.

venerate.sentence_1: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

vindicate.meaning_1: verb: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof
vindicate.sentence_1: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.

commensurate.meaning_1: adjective: to be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount
commensurate.sentence_1: The convicted felon’s life sentence was commensurate with the heinousness of his crime.

anomalous.sentence_1: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous—daily temperatures should return to their old averages, they believe.

veracious.sentence_1: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

ambivalent.meaning_1: adjective: mixed or conflicting emotions about something
ambivalent.sentence_1: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.

calumny.meaning_1: noun: making of a false statement meant to injure a person’s reputation
calumny.sentence_1: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny, and the mud already waist-high.

mercurial.meaning_1: adjective: (of a person) prone to unexpected and unpredictable changes in mood
mercurial.sentence_1: The fact that Ella’s moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships—it didn’t help that she lived in Chicago.

harangue.sentence_1: Dinner at Billy's was more a punishment than a reward, since anyone who sat at the dinner table would have to listen to Billy's father's interminable harangues against the government.
harangue.sentence_2: Tired of his parents haranguing him about his laziness and lack of initiative, Tyler finally moved out of home at the age of thirty-five.
harangue.meaning_2: verb: to deliver a long pompous speech or tirade
harangue.meaning_1: noun: a long pompous speech; a tirade

belie.meaning_1: verb: to give a false representation to; misrepresent
belie.sentence_1: The smile on her face belies the pain she must feel after the death of her husband.

acrimony.sentence_1: The acrimony between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.

demur.meaning_1: verb: to object or show reluctance
demur.sentence_1: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they go skiing in the Alps.

prevaricate.meaning_1: verb: to speak in an evasive way
prevaricate.sentence_1: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate”.

undermine.meaning_1: verb: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)
undermine.sentence_1: The student undermined the teacher’s authority by questioning the teacher’s judgment on numerous occasions.

enervate.sentence_1: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he’d spent the day sightseeing.

auspicious.meaning_1: adjective: favorable, the opposite of sinister
auspicious.sentence_1: Despite an auspicious beginning, Mike’s road trip became a series of mishaps, and he was soon stranded and penniless, leaning against his wrecked automobile.

parsimonious.sentence_1: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

innocuous.meaning_1: adjective: harmless and doesn’t produce any ill effects
innocuous.sentence_1: Everyone found Nancy’s banter innocuous—except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.

iconoclast.meaning_1: noun: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
iconoclast.sentence_1: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a "meat dress" to a prominent awards show.

censure.sentence_1: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

ingenuous.meaning_1: adjective: to be naïve and innocent
ingenuous.sentence_1: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

laconic.meaning_1: adjective: (describes a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words
laconic.sentence_1: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative—and not very hunky.

upbraid.sentence_1: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"—in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

frugal.meaning_1: adjective: not spending much money (but spending wisely)
frugal.sentence_1: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

aberration.meaning_1: noun: a deviation from what is normal or expected
aberration.sentence_1: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.

impertinent.meaning_1: adjective: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
impertinent.sentence_1: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer’s questions impertinent—after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline’s favorite snack was?

amenable.sentence_1: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

Magoosh.meaning_1: noun: An online GRE prep product used by tens of thousands of students worldwide. Learn more at gre.magoosh.com.
Magoosh.sentence_1: After using Magoosh, Tom improved his GRE score by 8 points and was then admitted into UC Berkeley.

chastise.sentence_1: Though chastised for eating the snacks for the party, Lawrence shrugged off his mother’s harsh words, and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of donuts.

castigate.sentence_1: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recruits so mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week in training.

wanting.sentence_1: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

disinterested.sentence_1: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

amorphous.sentence_1: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test prep books.

betray.meaning_1: verb: to reveal or make known something, usually unintentionally
betray.sentence_1: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.

profligate.sentence_1: The composer Wagner, while living on a limited salary, was so profligate as to line all the walls of his apartment with pure silk.
profligate.sentence_2: Most lottery winners go from being conservative, frugal types to outright profligates who blow millions on fast cars, lavish homes, and giant yachts.
profligate.meaning_2: noun: someone who spends resources recklessly or wastefully
profligate.meaning_1: adjective: spending resources recklessly or wastefully

prodigal.sentence_1: Successful professional athletes who do not fall prey to prodigality seem to be the exception—most live decadent lives.

intimate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
intimate.sentence_1: At first Manfred’s teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy’s precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the 6th grade.

parochial.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
parochial.meaning_1: adjective: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook
parochial.sentence_1: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial; "After all," she quipped on her blog, "he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food."

restive.sentence_1: The crowd grew restive as the comedian’s opening jokes fell flat.

amalgam.meaning_1: noun: a mixture of multiple things
amalgam.sentence_1: The band’s music was an amalgam of hip-hop, flamenco and jazz, blending the three styles with surprising results.

venality.meaning_1: noun: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption
venality.sentence_1: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

qualify.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions, but this is the most important one to study
qualify.meaning_1: verb: to make less severe; to limit (a statement)
qualify.sentence_1: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding he didn't like the weather there as much as he liked the weather in Los Angeles.

extant.meaning_1: adjective: still in existence (usually refers to documents).
extant.sentence_1: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

ambiguous.meaning_1: adjective: open to more than one interpretation
ambiguous.sentence_1: The coach told his team, “Move towards that side of the field”; because he did not point, his directions were ambiguous, and the team had no idea to which side he was referring.

artful.sentence_1: Picasso is generally considered the most artful member of the Cubist movement.
artful.sentence_2: Bernie Madoff's artful Ponzi scheme stole billions of dollars from investors and is considered the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.
artful.meaning_2: adjective: clever in a cunning way

gregarious.meaning_1: adjective: to be likely to socialize with others
gregarious.sentence_1: Often we think that great leaders are those who are gregarious, always in the middle of a large group of people; yet, as Mahatma Gandhi and many others have shown us, leaders can also be introverted.

involved.meaning_1: adjective: complicated, and difficult to comprehend
involved.sentence_1: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate’s eyes glazed over.

equivocal.sentence_1: The findings of the study were equivocal—the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.
